[[AB+M]]{{Cite news | edition = J - Generic Tabloid | page = 6 | title = Designing ways | work = [[The Courier-Mail]] | date = 2004-11-16 }} | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | awards = | designations = | ren_architect = | ren_firm = | ren_str_engineer = | ren_serv_engineer = | ren_civ_engineer = | ren_oth_designers = | ren_qty_surveyor = | ren_awards = | url = | embedded = | references = }} {{Refimprove|date=March 2009}} '''Brisbane Magistrates Court''' is located at 363 George Street, [[Brisbane]] in [[Queensland]], [[Australia]]. The building is a modern, purpose-built facility which currently contains 26 courtrooms. These include a dedicated Murri Court, two Coroners courts and four Small Claims hearing rooms.{{Cite news | edition = J - Generic Tabloid | page = 2 | last = Beattie | first = Peter |authorlink = Peter Beattie | title = Investment in law and order | work = [[The Courier-Mail]] | date = 2004-11-16 }}{{Cite news | edition = J - Generic Tabloid | page = 2 | last = Welford | first = Rod |authorlink = Rod Welford | title = Busy court is the place to be heard | work = [[The Courier-Mail]] | date = 2004-11-16 }}The building has the capacity to expand to 39 courtrooms. Construction started in September 2002 and the building was opened on 16 November 2004 by the Queensland Premier, Peter Beattie. The total budget for the project was $135.5m. The building was designed to provide improved support for victims and their families, and to vulnerable witnesses. It also contains a range of environmentally sustainable design initiatives including economy-cycle air conditioning, energy efficient lighting, rainwater tanks that hold 46 000 litres of water for use on external landscaping, motion sensors that lower air-conditioning and lighting when rooms are unoccupied, extensive use of passive sun control and low energy glass, solar hot water, and waste streaming systems. ==Public Art== The Brisbane Magistrates Court is one of the largest infrastructure projects to incorporate the Queensland Government's Art Built-in policy, which requires two per cent of the capital works budget to be spent on art projects within the development. The building features a range of public artworks including sculptures, murals and paintings.{{Cite news | edition = 2 - State - Main Country | page = 39 | last = Giles | first = Darrell | title = Legal eagles get thrown a curly one | work = [[The Sunday Mail (Brisbane)|The Sunday Mail]] | date = 2004-10-24 }} {{coord|-27.467923|153.021531|display=title}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== [http://www.citymakers.org/buildings-in-brisbane-dummy/127-brisbane-magistrates-court.html Urban design review of Brisbane Magistrates Court] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Brisbane]] [[Category:Courthouses in Queensland]]
